comments.content:
Those are the two hangul syllables that are pronounced hangeul, and mean hangul. I don't understand the question.

Dr. Ken Lunde  
Senior Computer Scientist, CJKV Type Development  
Adobe Systems Incorporated  
 [lunde@adobe.com](mailto:lunde@adobe.com)

Thank you!

The question is... what is the font? ;-)

I would need to consult my Korean typeface specimen books, which are in my office, but I am still at home. Clearly, it is a heavy sans serif design on which a shadow effect has been applied. We licensed a similar design from Hanyang in the 1990s, and the font is HYKakHeadlineStd-Bold. Here is a sample, using the same characters as shown above:

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20130207035853im_/http:/typophile.com/files/hykakheadlinestd-bold_6372.jpg)

Dr. Ken Lunde  
Senior Computer Scientist, CJKV Type Development  
Adobe Systems Incorporated  
 [lunde@adobe.com](mailto:lunde@adobe.com)

I checked my Korean typeface specimen books, and the typeface appears to be Hanyang's "HY Headline Bold," which is the non-squared version of HYKakHeadlineStd-Bold whose sample I provided above.

Dr. Ken Lunde  
Senior Computer Scientist, CJKV Type Development  
Adobe Systems Incorporated  
 [lunde@adobe.com](mailto:lunde@adobe.com)
Careful, Ken. You might become the go to man for all non-latin (kanji) typeface identifications. ;^)

Well, at least that'll keep me off the streets... ;-)

Dr. Ken Lunde  
Senior Computer Scientist, CJKV Type Development  
Adobe Systems Incorporated  
 [lunde@adobe.com](mailto:lunde@adobe.com)

Nice work, Doctor Ken. Thank you!

I will try to use you as the "go to man" for Kanji as sparingly as possible. ;^)

I don't know if you need an exact match, but if you do, your sample isn't in HY Headline Bold (sample below, condensed to 90%), although it's certainly a similar style.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20130207035853im_/http:/typophile.com/files/hangullll_5133.jpg)

Most Korean foundries have their own versions of "Headline (헤드라인)" designs of this style, such as HY Headline, Rix Headline, etc. They may be offered in angled (_gak_, 각) or round (_dunggeun_, 둥근) versions, hence the HY Kak Headline, _kak_ being an alternate romanization of 각.

"Headline" faces are also called _jemok_ (제목) faces, so you may also have to look through some _dunggeun jemok_ (둥근제목, round headline) faces offered by different foundries.

I haven't been able to find an exact match. It's not one of the usual suspects (Hanyang, Baekmuk, Sandoll, etc.) and I've exhausted the few specimens I have. Online samples are too small and most often don't include the glyphs "한글!". If you need an exact match, I can investigate further.

I've just realized where that sample is from:

[http://www.typography.com/ask/showBlog.php?blogID=141](http://web.archive.org/web/20130207035853/http:/www.typography.com/ask/showBlog.php?blogID=141 "http://www.typography.com/ask/showBlog.php?blogID=141")

It's from the Hoefler & Frere-Jones website.
